definition:
Let $I$ be an ideal of a semigroup $S$. Define a congruence $\sim$ by
$x \sim y$ iff $x = y$ or $x, y \in I$.

Then the *Rees factor* of $S$ by $I$ is the quotient $S/\sim$. As a
matter of notation, the congruence $\sim$ is normally suppressed, and
the quotient is simply written $S/I$.

Note that a Rees factor always has a zero element. Intuitively, the
quotient identifies all element in $I$ and the resulting element is a
zero element.
